description.narrative: 1: Increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level 3: Global learning and scaling network is established and functioning.

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative:
Below are the indicators for each Output:
Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries.
1.1 Number of new data sources used at Country Office level. 1.2 Diversity of different data sources used 1.3 Number of sustainable development solutions identified and documented 1.4 Variety of innovation methods used to test and iterate over the different hypotheses.
Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets.
2.1 Learning the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP) 2.2 Number of lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by governments or other partners 2.3 Proportion of partners and governments that increase their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite 2.4 Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies
Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning.
3.1 Size and density of the network effects among the Accelerator Labs 3.2 Number of new models, approaches, and insights documented and disseminated throughout the network. 3.3 Engagement of the broader Development ecosystem with published learnings from the Accelerator Lab Network. 3.4 Amount of influence the learnings and methods of the Accelerator Lab Networks have on the discourse of the broader Development ecosystem.

comment.narrative: The Ghana Accelerator Lab was onboarded in October 2019, and started operating fully in 2020. Hence, our baseline Year is 2019.

1.1 2 new sources of data per year 1.2 3 different type of data sources per year 1.3 20 new potential solutions per lab per year 1.4 2 innovation methods per Action Plan 2.1 3 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 2.2 At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart. 2.3 At least one government entity or partner has learned about Accelerator lab methods. 2.4 At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects. 3.1 The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network. (48 interaction per year) 3.2 5% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 3.3 The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 2 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. 3.4 Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 2 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.

1.1 2 1.2 3 1.3 10 1.4 2 2.1 1 2.2 50% 2.3 2 2.4 50% 3.1 At least once a week (20 in 2019) 3.2 5% 3.3 3 times a month; at least once a month across any social media 3.4 Engaged with 5 new relevant local social media profiles of the local innovation ecosystem

Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries.
1.1 5 new data sources per year 1.2 6 different type of data sources per year 1.3 35 new potential solutions per lab per year 1.4 5 innovation methods per Action Plan
Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets.
2.1 6 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 2.2 At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as counterpart 2.3 At least one government entity or partner has learned about Accelerator lab methods 2.4 At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects.
Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning.
3.1 The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network. 48 interaction per year 3.2 25% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 3.3 The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. 3.4 Identify and engage with 5 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.

Results for Output 1:
1.1 New sources of data
(Target: 2 new sources of data per year)
a)Ghana Statistical Service (GSS) Call Details Records and Mobility Analysis: Use of anonymised and aggregated data from Mobile Network Operators (MNOs) as a key data source for understanding the mobility patterns of populations, and improving decision-making and scenario planning.
Two Mobility analysis reports on the use of anonymized call detail records to support the Government of Ghana in responding to the COVID-19 outbreak are available on the GSS website here:
COVID-19 press release report - analysis overview - final1.pdf (statsghana.gov.gh) COVID-19 press release report - analysis overview - final.pdf (statsghana.gov.gh)
b) Ghana Statistical Service (GSS) COVID-19 Monitoring Dashboard
c) GHANA COVID-19 MONITORING DASHBOARD (arcgis.com)
d) COVID-19 Data Futures Platform - https://data.undp.org/ The COVID-19 Data Futures Platform pulls together data from the UN system, nonprofit partners, academia, development partners and countries around the world. Interactive tools provide unique opportunities for data analysis, insights identification, and collaboration around strategies and solutions. Analytics and data presented will dynamically evolve, responding to different questions that arise as the situation changes.
e) TransGov (Ghana) Open Data to enable citizens to monitor and comment on the implementation and progress of developmental projects in their local communities and nationwide. Projects | TransGov (transgovgh.org)
f) The Humanitarian Data Exchange - Digital platform for finding and sharing humanitarian data. Humanitarian Data Exchange (humdata.org)
1.2 Different type of data sources (Target: 3 different type of data sources per year)
a) Data from Innovation Challenges: Analytics on participants in the Multi-city Challenge Africa, detailing types of innovations received, location and gender of applicants, etc Analytics on COVID-19 Innovation Challenge winners, detailing types of innovations received, location of submissions, gender of applicants, business or production stage.
b) Ethnographic data : data gathered from interviews with residents, market leaders, local businesses in the Tudu enclave and Abuja slums of Accra to deepen our understanding of why deepen our understanding of why formal waste management services are not effective in slums
c) Satellite data : we supported Jekora Ventures to digitally map 350+ households using Geographic information systems software. Each household and vendor in the project location is mapped, and the database contains demographic information for easy identification and revenue management
1.3 Potential new solutions mapped by the Lab (Target: 20 new potential solutions per lab per year)
Over 200 solutions mapped through the Covid Innovation Challenge and other solutions mapping activities. Below are links to these solutions:
[Innovation Database (Solution Mapping Repository) ] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DNopa3ykGF0 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ISbVF4_WsBQ&t=1s
1.4 Innovation methods applied (Target: 2 innovation methods per Action Plan)
a) Collective Intelligence and ethnographic methods were applied to study community waste management in low income areas b) Behavioral Insights methods were applied to increase plastics recycling rates at community recycling banks c) Collective Intelligence and crowdsourcing methods were employed in a challenge aimed at tackling urban development issues in collaboration with the Singapore Centre as part of the Multi-City Africa Challenge d) Collective Intelligence used to co-design a workable waste collection approach for slum settlements and to digitally map all households and structures for better waste management.
Results for Output 2:
2.1 Blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published (Target: 3 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year)
Eco-conscious Kofi and Just-passing Ama – Experiments by UNDP Ghana’s Accelerator Lab on recycling | UNDP in Ghana Crisis is the Mother of Invention: Mitigating COVID-19 through Innovation | UNDP in Ghana COVID-19 Innovation Challenge - Creating the “New Normal” and Building the Recovery | UNDP in Ghana UNDP Ghana announces 22 winners of its COVID-19 Innovation Challenge | UNDP in Ghana Changing behaviour: lessons in community waste management in Ghana | UNDP in Ghana Partnership for cleaner cities: Addressing improper waste management in Africa
2.2 Public sector or other partners engaged about the Lab’s learning challenges (Target: At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector or other partner as a counterpart)
a) Ghana Recycling Initiative by Private Enterprises (GRIPE) - subgroup of the Association of Ghana Industries b) Ghana Federation of Disability Organisations c) Ministry of Environment, Science, Technology and Innovation (MESTI) d) Klottey Korley Municipal Assembly (KOKMA) e) Accra Metropolitan Asembly (AMA)
2.3 Government entities or partners informed about Accelerator Lab methods (Target: At least one government entity or partner has learned about Accelerator lab methods)
a) Accra Metropolitan Assembly + multidisciplinary problem definition training sessions facilitated by NYU’s GovLab as part of our partnership on the Multi-City Africa Challenge b) Ghana Statistical Service - informed about the Accelerator Lab activities during meetings to discuss the Data for Good Call Detail Records project. c) Centre for Scientific and Industrial Research -Science and Technology Policy Research Institute (CSIR-STEPRI) - were introduced to the Accelerator Lab during the Situational Analysis of STI for SDGs Workshop d) SDGs Advisory Unit, Office of the President engaged during the Situational Analysis of STI for SDGs Workshop
2.4 CO Projects benefiting from actionable knowledge from the Lab’s learning challenges. (Target: At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects)
a. Environment and Climate Cluster: Waste Recovery Platform - UNDP provides a convening platform for Government, policy-makers, the private sector, NGOs and the informal sector on issues relating to developing a circular economy in waste. Benefits derived were in bringing behavioral methodologies (particularly Behavioral Insights) into the project’s work, leading to the scoping of a set of projects using behavioral methods.
b. The AccLab also partnered with the Waste Recovery Platform in the production of a Solutions Mapping video aimed at highlighting the face of non-formal innovation in plastics recycling. Finally, the AccLab was also invited to speak, and presented on a global COVID-19 webinar (Ghana’s Waste Recovery Platform and COVID-19: promoting inclusion and innovation) led by the Cluster
c. The AccLab applied its knowledge of data mapping and new data methods to support the Governance cluster in brainstorming, developing and implementing the 2020 Election Hotseat - a citizen education game that offered an entertaining medium of educating voters about Ghana’s electoral rules, sanctions, and recommended code of conduct before, during, and after the elections.
Results for Output 3 3.1 Interaction with other labs in the network. (Target: The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network. (48 interaction per year))
The Ghana AccLab had discussions with more than 10 other labs on a weekly basis for five months (February - June 2020) during the Collective Intelligence Design Lab, and we continued to engage with multiple labs throughout the year. Below are our key highlights after June 2020:
a. Ghana AccLab shared lessons with Niger AccLab on “100 day cycle- Waste Management and Recovery in Urban Areas - Nov 2020 b. Ghana AccLab shared lessons and delivered a presentation to Maldives AccLab on Behavioral Insights and Plastic Waste - Jan 2021
3.2 Methodology, sustainable development issues and opportunity related Information shared across the network (Target: 5% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issues and opportunity related)
More than 50% of our discussions with other Labs, information shared on Teams and WhatsApp, and our engagements on Twitter and LinkedIn are related to our learning challenges, development issues and opportunities identified, and methodologies applied in our work.
3.3 Lab’s work featured in CO Social Media Accounts (Target: The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 2 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts)
(#Acclabgh - Twitter Search / Twitter (3) UNDP Ghana on Twitter: Resilience & creativity are critical in fighting #COVID19 and @UNDPAccLabs are uniquely placed to support #innovation. @Allen_Anie @UNDP outlines emerging local innovations & a forthcoming Innovation Challenge to support innovation ecosystem in #Ghana. https://t.co/lfxhwa4edS / Twitter https://sdgactionzone.org/class/innovative-solutions-grassroots-local-innovations-to-accelerate-action/ https://twitter.com/FaroutaZ https://twitter.com/UNDPGhana/status/1309174991565590531 https://twitter.com/UNDPAccLabs/status/1374423673503768580 https://twitter.com/FutureProofHlth/status/1384801862751227904
